question: Q1
solution: Product of Eigen value = determinant value [latex] \begin{array}{l} =2(3-6)+1(8-0) \\ =2(-3)+8=-6+8=2 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Q2
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x^{3}-\sin x}{x} &=\left(\frac{0}{0} \mathrm{form}\right) \\ \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3 x^{2}-\cos x}{1} &=0-\cos 0 \\ &=0-1=-1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q3
solution: [latex]\small \begin{aligned} u &=f(x-c y) \\ \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} &=f^{\prime}(x-c y)(1) \\ \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} &=f^{\prime}(x-c y)(-c) \\ &=-c \cdot f^{\prime}(x-c y)\\ &=-c \cdot \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} \\ \therefore  \quad \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} & +c \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} =0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q4
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(d^{2}+16\right) y &=0 \\ A E \text { is } m^{2}+16 &=0 \\ m &=\pm 4 i \end{aligned}[/latex] Solution is [latex] y=c_{1} \cos 4 x+c_{2} \sin 4 x[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} y' &=-4 c_{1} \sin 4 x+4 c_{2} \cos 4 x \\ y'(0) &=1 \\ 1 &=4 c_{2} \\ c_{2} &=1 / 4 \\ y'(\pi / 2) &=-1 \\ -1 &=-4 c_{1} \sin 2 \pi+4 c_{2} \cos 2 \pi \\ -1 &=0+4 c_{2} \\ c_{2} &=-1 / 4 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore the given differential equation has no solution.

question: Q6
solution: The average velocity in pipe flow always be same either for developing flow or fully developed flow.

options.A: It increases until the flow is fully developed.
options.B: It is constant and is eaual to the average velocity in the fully devloped region.
options.C: It decreases until the flow is fully developed
options.D: It is constant but is always lower than the average velocity in the fully devloped region.

question: Q7
solution: Given that the flow is incompressible. [latex] \therefore \quad \operatorname{div} \bar{V}=0 [/latex] [latex] \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(5+a_{1} x+b_{1} y\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(8+a_{2} x+b_{2} y\right)=0 [/latex] [latex] a_{1}+b_{2}=0[/latex]

question: Q8
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \rho &=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ m &=1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \\ \Delta p &=100 \mathrm{kPa}=100 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{Pa} \\ P &=\rho Q g h_{f} \\ &=Q \Delta p \\ &=\frac{m}{\rho} \Delta p=\frac{1}{1000} \times 100 \times 10^{3} \\ &=100 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q9
solution: In the given options all the pumps have rotating machine elements except Jet pump. Centrifugal pump: It has rotating part eg.,impeller, Vane. Gear Pump: In this pump there is gear mechanism which is rotating part. Jet Pump: Jet pump utilizes ejector principle which have nozzle and diffuser not rotating parts. Vane Pump: It consist of rotating disc which called as rotor in which number of radial slots are there where sliding vanes is inserted.

question: Q10
solution: Temperature profiles are [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta T_{i}=100-20=80^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \Delta T_{e}=100-50=50^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] (LMTD) (parallel or counter HE) [latex] \begin{aligned} =\frac{\Delta T_{i}-\Delta T_{e}}{\ln \frac{\Delta T_{i}}{\Delta T_{e}}}=\frac{80-50}{\ln \frac{80}{50}} \\ =63.82^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q11
solution: Given that:[latex] \bar{C}_{v}=2.5 \bar{R} [/latex] [latex] \bar{C}_{v} \rightarrow [/latex] Molar specific heat at constant volume [latex] \begin{aligned} \bar{C}_{p}-\bar{C}_{v}&=\bar{R}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \bar{C}_{p}&=\bar{R}+\bar{C}_{v}=\bar{R}+2.5 \bar{R} \\ \bar{C}_{p}&=3.5 \bar{R} \end{aligned}[/latex] Molar specific enthalpy change of ideal gas (A H) [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta H &=n \bar{C}_{p} \Delta T \\ \overline{\Delta H} &=\frac{\Delta H}{n}=\overline{\Delta H}=\bar{C}_{p} \Delta T \\ &=3.5 \times 8.314 \times 100 \\ \overline{\Delta H} &=2909.9 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{mole} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q12
solution: Given that: [latex] \dot{Q}_{L}=10 \mathrm{kW} [/latex] [latex]\dot{W}=15 \mathrm{kW}[/latex] Applying first law on heat pump [latex] \begin{array}{c} \dot{Q}_{L}+\dot{W}=\dot{Q}_{H} \\ 10 \mathrm{kW}+15 \mathrm{kW}=\dot{Q}_{H} \\ \dot{Q}_{H}=25 \mathrm{kW} \\ (\mathrm{COP})_{\mathrm{H.P.}}=\frac{\dot{Q}_{H}}{\dot{W}}=\frac{25 \mathrm{kW}}{15 \mathrm{kW}}=1.67 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Q13
solution: For perfectly incompressible material, poisson's ratio =0.5 (if change in vol. should be zero,[latex] \mu=0.5[/latex])

question: Q14
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned} r &=t^{2}: \theta=t \\ \mathrm{K.E} &=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=? \text { at } t=2 \mathrm{sec} \\ \Rightarrow m &=1 \mathrm{kg} \\ \vec{V} &=r \omega(\hat{t})+\frac{d r}{d t} \dot{r}=t^{2} \times 1(\hat{t})+2 t \hat{r} \\ \therefore \frac{d \theta}{d t}&=\omega=1
\\ \vec{V} &=t^{2}(\hat{t})+2 t(\hat{r}) \\ \text{at }\qquad t &=2 s \\ \vec{V} &=4(\hat{t})+4(\hat{r}) \\ |\vec{V}| &=\sqrt{16+16}=\sqrt{32} \\ K.E. &=\frac{1}{2}mv^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\times1\times32=16 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q15
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T &=\frac{P \times 60 \times 10^{6}}{2 \pi N}=\frac{40 \times 60 \times 10^{6}}{2 \pi(500)} \\ &=763943.7268 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{mm} \\ \tau_{\max } &=\frac{16 T}{\pi d^{3}}=\frac{16 \times 763943.7268}{\pi(40)^{3}} \\ &=60.792 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q16
solution: [latex]\frac{I_{N . A}}{Z_{N . A}}=\frac{I_{N, A_{.}}}{\left(I_{N . A} / Y_{\max }\right)}=Y_{\max }[/latex] For a solid circular cross-section [latex] Y_{\max }=d / 2[/latex]

question: Q17
solution: V-t curve Distance travelled is asked from t=0 to 5 s [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=\frac{d S}{d t} \\ d S &=V d t \\ S &=\int_{0}^{5} V d t \end{aligned}[/latex] Area of V-t graph plotted on time axis from 0 to 5s [latex] \begin{aligned} S &=\frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times 1+1 \times 1 \times \frac{1}{2}[1+4] \times 1 \\ & +\frac{1}{2}[4+2] \times 2 \\ &=10 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q18
solution: We know that: [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 \xi \omega_{n} &=\frac{c}{m} \\ \xi &=\frac{c}{m \times 2 \omega_{n}}=\frac{c}{2 m \cdot \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}}=\frac{c}{2 \sqrt{k m}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q19
solution: Safe condition to avoid tearing failure of the joint along the row of rivets, [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(\sigma_{\text {max }}\right)_{\text {tensile }} & \leq\left(\sigma_{t}\right)_{\text {per }} \\ \frac{F}{(W-2 d) t} &=S_{f} \\ t & \geq \frac{F}{S_{f}(W-2 d)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q20
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C p &=\frac{U S L-L S L}{6 \sigma} \\ &=\frac{15.02-14.98}{6 \times 0.004}=1.667 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q21
solution: Safe condition for design as per von-Mises criterion, [latex] \sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2}-\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2} \leq\left(\frac{S_{y t}}{N}\right)^{2}[/latex] When yielding occurs, N=1 [latex] \begin{array}{r} \sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2}-\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2}=\left(S_{y t}\right)^{2} \\ (180)^{2}+(-100)^{2}-(180)(-100)=\left(S_{y t}\right)^{2} \\ S_{t y}=245.7641 \mathrm{MPa} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Q23
solution: [latex]H_{s}=\frac{V I}{v A_{b}}[/latex] If v is doubled (2 v) to make [latex]H_{s}[/latex] constant [latex]A_{b}[/latex] will be reduced by 50% [latex] H_{s}=\frac{V I}{2 v \frac{A_{b}}{2}}=\frac{V I}{v A_{b}}[/latex]

question: Q24
solution: Pitch of thread, [latex] P_{t}=0.8 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Speed of spindle, [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{t} &=1500 \mathrm{rpm} \\ P_{s} &=1.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ N_{s} \times P_{s} \times Z_{z} &=N_{t} \times P_{t} \times Z_{t}\left[\because z_{s}=z_{t}=1\right] \\ N_{s} \times 1.5 \times 1 &=1500 \times 0.8 \times 1 \\ N_{s} &=800 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q25
solution: Ultimate tensile strength represents the max. stress that a material can withstand without fracture.

question: Q26
solution:
Explanations: The Eigen values of an orthogonal 
 matrix are of magnitude 1 and are real (a) complex 
 conjugate pairs

options.A: Determinant of P is equal to 1.
options.C: Inverse of P is equal to its transpose.
options.D: All Eigen values of P are real numbers.

question: Q27
solution: By vector identities [latex]div.(crul\bar{F}) = 0[/latex]

question: Q28
solution: [latex]x = \cos \left( \frac { \pi u } { 2 } \right) ; \quad y = \sin \left( \frac { \pi u } { 2 } \right) [/latex] [latex] x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } = 1 [/latex] represents a circle in x - y plane. [latex] \begin{aligned} 0 &\leq u \leq 1 \text { (given range) } \\ \therefore 0 &\leq x \leq 1,0 \leq y \leq 1 \\ so, 0 &\leq \theta \leq \frac { \pi } { 2 } \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Thus, we will get as quarter circle in x-y plane. Therefore, Area of hemisphere[latex] = 2 \pi(r^{2})=2\pi \times (1^{2}) = 2\pi[/latex]

question: Q29
solution: By Trapezoidal rule [latex] \begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{1} f(x) d x &=\frac{h}{2}\left[\left(y_{0}+y_{2}\right)+2 y_{1}\right] \\ &=\frac{0.5}{2}[(3+5)+2(4)]=4 \end{aligned} [/latex] By Simpson rule [latex] \int_{0}^{1} f(x) d x=\frac{h}{3}\left[\left(y_{0}+y_{2}\right)+4 y_{1}\right] [/latex] [latex] =\frac{0.5}{3}[(3+5)+4(4)]=4 [/latex] The difference between the two results will be zero.

question: Q30
solution: Given [latex]\quad \frac{u}{U_{\infty}}=\sin \left(\frac{\pi}{2} \frac{y}{\delta}\right) [/latex] where [latex]\quad \delta= [/latex] Boundary layer thickness Local displacement thickness, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta^{*}&=\int_{0}^{\delta}\left(1-\frac{u}{U_{\infty}}\right) d y \\ &=\int_{0}^{\delta}\left[1-\sin \left(\frac{\pi y}{2 \delta}\right)\right] d y \\ &=\left[y+\frac{2 \delta}{\pi} \times \cos \left(\frac{\pi y}{2 \delta}\right)\right]_{0}^{\delta} \\ &=\left[\delta+0-0-\frac{2 \delta}{\pi}\right] \\ \delta^{*}&=\delta\left(1-\frac{2}{\pi}\right)\\ or,\quad \frac{\delta^{*}}{\delta}&=1-\frac{2}{\pi} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q31
solution: For series connection, [latex] Q_{1}=Q_{2}=Q[/latex] As given [latex]\quad l_{1}=l_{2}=l [/latex] For horizontal pipe, [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{f}&=\Delta p \\ h_{f_{1}}&=\frac{f_{1} L Q^{2}}{12.1 d_{1}^{5}} ; \quad h_{f_{2}}=\frac{f_{2} L Q^{2}}{12.1 d_{2}^{5}} \\ \frac{\Delta P_{1}}{\Delta P_{2}}&=\frac{f_{1}}{d_{1}^{5}} \times \frac{d_{2}^{5}}{f_{2}} \\ f&=\frac{k}{\operatorname{Re}^{n}}=\frac{k}{\left(\frac{V D}{v}\right)^{n}} \\ Q&=\frac{\pi}{4} D^{2} \times V \\ V &\propto \frac{1}{D^{2}} \\ f &\propto \frac{1}{\left(\frac{1}{D^{2}} D\right)^{n}} \end{aligned}[/latex] By equation (i) [latex]f \propto D^{n} [/latex] [latex] \frac{\Delta P_{1}}{\Delta P_{2}}=\frac{d_{1}^{n}}{d_{1}^{5}} \times \frac{d_{2}^{5}}{d_{2}^{n}}[/latex] [latex] \frac{\Delta P_{1}}{\Delta P_{2}}=\frac{d_{2}^{5-n}}{d_{1}^{5-n}}[/latex]

question: Q32
solution: Given velocity field, [latex] \vec{V}=\left(-x^{2}+3 y\right) \hat{i}+(2 x y) \hat{j}[/latex] [latex] where \quad u=-x^{2}+3 y \text { and } v=2 x y[/latex] The acceleration components along x and y -axis. [latex] \begin{aligned} a_{x}&=u \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+v \frac{\partial u}{\partial y}\\ \text{and}\quad a_{y} &=u \frac{\partial v}{\partial x}+v \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} \\ &=\left(-x^{2}+3 y\right) \times(-2 x)+2 x y \times 3 \\ &=2 x^{3}-6 x y+6 x y=2 x^{3}\\ \text{and}\quad a_{y} &=\left(-x^{2}+3 y\right) \times 2 y+2 x y \times 2 x \\ &=-2 y x^{2}+6 y^{2}+4 x^{2} y=2 y x^{2}+6 y^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] At point (1,-1) [latex] \begin{aligned} a_{x}&=2\\ \text{and}\quad a_{y} &=2 \times(-1) \times 1+6 \times(-1)^{2} \\ &=-2+6=4 \\ \vec{a} &=a_{x} \hat{i}+a_{y} \hat{j}=2 i+4 \hat{j} \end{aligned}[/latex] Resultant acceleration: [latex] \begin{aligned} a &=\sqrt{4+16}=\sqrt{20} \\ &=\sqrt{4 \times 5}=2 \sqrt{5} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q33
solution: [latex]m=1 \mathrm{kg} ; \quad R=400 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{k}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} c_{v}&=1000 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{K} \\ T_{i}&=300 \mathrm{K} ; P_{i}=100 \mathrm{kPa} \\ W&=100 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying first law: [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\Delta U+W\\ \Rightarrow \quad 0&=m c_{v}\left(T_{f}-T_{i}\right)+(-100) \times 10^{3} J \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0&=1 \times 1000 \times\left(T_{f}-300\right)-100 \times 10^{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{f}&=400 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Entropy change for ideal gas [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta S &=m\left[C_{v} \ln \frac{T_{f}}{T_{i}}+R \ln \frac{V_{f}}{V_{i}}\right] \quad \because V_{i}=V_{f} \\ &=1 \times\left[1000 \ln \frac{400}{300}+0\right] \\ &=287.682 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q34
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given data:}\;\mathrm{c}_{p}&=1040 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} ; \gamma=1.4 ; r_{p}=10; \\ T_{3}&=1200 \mathrm{K};\;\eta=0.9 \\ \frac{T_{7}}{T_{4 s}}&=\left(r_{p}\right) \frac{\gamma-1}{\gamma} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1200}{T_{4 s}} &=(10)^{(1.4-1) / 1.4} \\ \text { or } \quad T_{4 s} &=621.53 \mathrm{K} \\ \eta_{T} &=\frac{T_{3}-T_{4}}{T_{3}-T_{4 s}} \\ 0.9 &=\frac{1200-T_{4}}{1200-621.53} \\ \text{or}\qquad T_{4} &=679.4 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q35
solution: Relative humidity: [latex] \begin{aligned} \phi &=\frac{p_{v}}{p_{v s}} \\ 0.55 &=\frac{p_{v}}{4246}\\ \text { or } \quad p_{v}&=2335.3 \mathrm{Pa}=2.335 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \therefore \quad \omega &=\frac{(\mathrm{Mol} \cdot \mathrm{wt})_{\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}}{(\mathrm{Mol} \cdot \mathrm{w} \mathrm{t})_{\mathrm{air}}} \times\left(\frac{p_{v}}{p-p_{v}}\right) \\ &=\frac{18}{28.84} \times\left(\frac{2.335}{100-2.335}\right) \\ &=0.01492 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kg} \text { of d.a } \\ \text { also } \quad \omega &=\frac{m_{v}}{m_{a}} \\ \therefore \quad 0.01492 &=\frac{m_{v}}{1}\\ \text{or }\quad m_{v}&=0.01492 \mathrm{kg}=14.92 \mathrm{gm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q36
solution: Stoichiometrically balanced equation for combustion of [latex]{\mathrm{CH}}_4[/latex] [latex]{\mathrm{CH}}_4+2{\mathrm O}_2\rightarrow{\mathrm{CO}}_2+2{\mathrm H}_2\mathrm O[/latex] Actual moles of [latex]{\mathrm{O}}_2[/latex] used [latex]=2\times\left(\frac{150}{100}\right)=3[/latex] moles of [latex]{\mathrm{O}}_2[/latex] Actual equation [latex]{\mathrm{CH}}_4+3{\mathrm o}_2\rightarrow{\mathrm{Co}}_2+2{\mathrm H}_2\mathrm o+{\mathrm O}_2[/latex] Consider Air instead of pure [latex]{\mathrm{O}}_2[/latex] [latex]{\mathrm{CH}}_4+\left[3{\mathrm o}_2+3\left(\frac{79}{21}\right){\mathrm N}_2\right]\rightarrow{\mathrm{Co}}_2+2{\mathrm H}_2\mathrm O+{\mathrm O}_2+\frac{79}7\mathrm N2[/latex] Total moles in product  [latex]=1+2+1+\frac{79}7=15.285[/latex] Molar percentage of [latex]{\mathrm N}_2=\frac{11.285}{15.285}\times100=73.830\%[/latex]

question: Q37
solution: Marks to All as per IIT official Answer [latex]F_{12} =0.5[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{1} &=800 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{2} &=600 \mathrm{K} \\ T_{\text {surounding }} &=300 \mathrm{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Let (3) denote the surrounding environment (Assume unit width perpendicular to plane of Fig.) From summation rule: [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{21}+F_{\beta 2}^{0}+F_{23} &=1 \\ A_{1} F_{12} &=A_{2} F_{21}=6 \times 1 \times 0.5 \\ &=(5 \times 1) \times F_{21} \\ F_{21} &=\frac{6 \times 0.5}{5}=0.6\\ \therefore \quad F_{23}&=1-F_{21}=0.4 \end{aligned}[/latex] since surrounding environment being large, No surface has a surface resistance. Heat transfer rate from (2) and (3)[latex]=\frac{E_{b_{2}}-E_{b_{3}}}{\frac{1}{A_{2} F_{23}}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\sigma\left(T_{2}^{4}-T_{3}^{4}\right)}{1} \\ &=\frac{5.67 \times 10^{-8}\left(600^{4}-300^{4}\right)}{A_{2} F_{23}} \text { watt/metre }\\ &=13.778 \mathrm{kW} / \mathrm{metre} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Assume that heat exchange is per unit width perpendicular to plane of figure

question: Q38
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{0}&= \text{ Temp. of cylinder at the axis}\\ T_{S} &=\text { Surface Temp. of Rod (cylindel) } \\ T_{O}-T_{S} &=\frac{\dot{q}}{4 k} R^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \dot{q}[/latex] uniform heat generation rate per unit volumne [latex] \left(w / m^{3}\right) [/latex] [latex] T_{0}-T_{S}=\frac{4 \times 10^{7}}{4 \times 25} \times\left(\frac{5}{1000}\right)^{2}=10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex]

question: Q39
solution: Condition for buckling, (Reaction offered by the fixed support)[latex]\gt [/latex] Buckling load [latex] \begin{aligned} i.e. R&>P e\\ \sigma_{\mathrm{Th}} A>& \frac{\pi^{2} E I_{\mathrm{min}}}{L_{e}^{2}} \\ \alpha(\Delta T) E A>& \frac{\pi^{2} E I_{\min }}{\left(L_{\theta}\right)^{2}}\\ \text{for cicular cross-section}\\ \alpha(\Delta T) E \frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} &>\frac{\pi^{2} E}{\left(L_{e}\right)^{2}} \frac{\pi}{64} d^{4} \\ \Delta T &>\frac{\pi^{2} d^{2}}{16 \alpha\left(L_{\theta}\right)^{2}} \\ \text{Hence,}\quad \Delta T & \propto d^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q40
solution: Given loading is impact loading [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta_{\text {impact }} &=\delta_{\text {static }} \times \text { Impact factor } \\ \delta_{\text {static }} &=\frac{W L}{A E}=\frac{100 \times 10 \times 1000}{100 \times 100 \times 10^{3}} \\ &=0.1 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Impact factor (I.F.) [latex] =1+\sqrt{1+\frac{2 h}{\delta_{\text {static }}}}[/latex] [latex] =1+\sqrt{1+\frac{2 \times 10}{0.1}}=15.178[/latex] Hence maximum compression of bar = Impact elongation [latex] =0.1 \times 15.178=1.5178 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Q41
solution: [latex]m_{A}=m_{B}=m[/latex] Outer circumferential radius of both disc A and B is also same i.e. R [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{A}&=m R^{2} \\ I_{B}&=\frac{m R^{2}}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \frac{V_{A}}{V_{B}} [/latex] at bottom of plane =? [latex] m g h=(K \cdot E) [/latex] of disc [latex]A=K \cdot E [/latex] of disc B [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} m V_{A}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I_{A} \omega_{A}^{2} &=\frac{1}{2} m V_{B}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I_{B} \omega_{B}^{2} \\ \frac{1}{2} m V_{A}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m R^{2} \frac{V_{A}^{2}}{R^{2}} &=\frac{1}{2} m V_{B}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \frac{m R^{2}}{2} \times \frac{V_{B}^{2}}{R^{2}} \\ \frac{V_{A}^{2}}{2}+\frac{V_{A}^{2}}{2} &=\frac{V_{B}^{2}}{2}+\frac{V_{B}^{2}}{4} \\ V_{A}^{2} &=\frac{3}{4} V_{B}^{2} \\ \frac{V_{A}}{V_{B}} &=\sqrt{\frac{3}{4}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q42
solution: [latex]\tan \theta=\frac{4}{3}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta &=53.13^{\circ} \\ 2 \theta &=106.26^{\circ} \\ \cos 2 \theta &=-0.27999 \\ \sin 2 \theta &=0.96 \end{aligned}[/latex] Normal strain on a oblique plane (i.e. RP) inclined at an angle [latex](\theta)[/latex] is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(\varepsilon_{n}\right)_{\theta}=& \frac{1}{2}\left[\varepsilon_{x}+\varepsilon_{y}\right]+\frac{1}{2}\left[\varepsilon_{x}-\varepsilon_{y}\right] \cos 2 \theta \\ & +\left(\frac{\gamma x y}{2}\right) \sin 2 \theta \\ =& \frac{1}{2}[0.001+0.002]+\frac{1}{2}[0.001-0.002] \\ &[-0.27999]+\left(\frac{0.003}{2}\right)(0.96) \\ &\left(\varepsilon_{n}\right)_{\theta=53.13^{\circ}}=0.00308 & \\ =& \frac{\text { Change in length of diagonal }}{\text { Original length of diagonal }}=0.00308 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, change in length of diagonal [latex] =(0.00308) 5=0.0154 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] deformed length of diagonal [latex] =5+0.0154=5.0154 \mathrm{mm}[/latex]

question: Q43
solution: From two similar triangles, [latex] (i.e. \Delta A B D \text { and } \Delta E C D) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{A B}{E C}&=\frac{B D}{C D} \\ \frac{\left(\log _{10} 480-\log _{10} 250\right)}{\left(\log _{10} S-\log _{10}-250\right)}&=\frac{6-3}{6-\log _{10} 10000} \\ \frac{2.68124-2.39794}{\log _{10} S-2.39794}&=1.5 \\ S&=386.195 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q44
solution: Change in length of small strip, [latex] \delta=\frac{P_{x-x}(d x)}{A_{x-x} E_{x x}}[/latex] Total change in length of bar, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta_{\text {total }} &=\int_{0}^{L} \delta=\int_{0}^{L} \frac{\left(P_{x-x}\right)(d x)}{\left(A_{x-x}\right) E_{x-x}} \\ P_{x-x} &=P=\text { Constant } \\ A_{x-x} &=A=\text { Constant } \\ E_{x-x} &=100 e^{-x} \text { GPA } \\ \delta_{\text {tolal }} &=\frac{P}{A} \int_{0}^{L} \frac{d x}{100 e^{-x}} \\ &=\frac{P}{10^{9} \times 100 A} \int_{0}^{L} \frac{d x}{e^{-x}} \\ &=\frac{10000}{1000 \times \frac{100 \times 10^{9}}{10^{6}} }\int_{0}^{1}\frac{d x}{e^{-x}} \\ &=\frac{1}{1000}[1.7183] m \\ \text{Hence,}\quad &=1.7183 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q45
solution: We take convention clockwise (+ve) [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{D} &=0 \\ N_{S} &=-100 \\ T_{S} &=50, \quad T_{P}=25, T_{D}=100 \\ \frac{N_{P}}{N_{\mathrm{ARM}}}&=? \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] y+x=-100 \qquad \cdots(i)[/latex] [latex] y-\frac{x}{2}=0 \qquad \cdots(ii)[/latex] By equation (i) - (ii) [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{3 x}{2} &=-100=x=\frac{-200}{3} \\ y &=-100-x=-100+\frac{200}{3}=\frac{-100}{3} \\ N_{p} &=y-2 x=\frac{-100}{3}+\frac{400}{3}=\frac{300}{3}=100 \\ N_{\mathrm{ARM}} &=y=\frac{-100}{3} \\ \frac{N_{P}}{N_{\mathrm{ARM}}} &=\frac{100}{\frac{-100}{3}}=-3 \\ \left| \frac{N_{\mathrm{P}}}{N_{\mathrm{ARM}}}\right | &=3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q46
solution: Taking Mass moment of inertia about point 0, [latex] \begin{aligned} I &=\frac{M l^{2}}{12}+M\left(\frac{l}{2}-\frac{l}{3}\right)^{2}+m \times\left(\frac{2 l}{3}\right)^{2} \\ &=\frac{M l^{2}}{12}+\frac{M l^{2}}{36}+\frac{4 M l^{2}}{9} \\ &=\frac{M l^{2}}{9}+\frac{4 M l^{2}}{4 \times 9}=\frac{2 M l^{2}}{9} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now we will balance torque about 0 [latex] \begin{aligned} I \alpha &=k \times \frac{2 L}{3} \times\left(\frac{2 L}{3} \theta\right)+k \times \frac{L}{3} \times\left(\frac{L}{3} \theta\right) \\ \frac{2 M l^{2}}{9} \frac{d^{2} \theta}{d t^{2}} &=\frac{5 k}{2 M}=\omega_{n}^{2} \theta \\ \therefore \quad \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{5 k}{2 M}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q47
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Here } & V_{B}=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ & \omega_{\text {crank }}=? \end{aligned}[/latex] Let us draw the I-centres Applying angular velocity theorem at [latex]I_{24} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \therefore \omega_{2}\left(I_{24} I_{12}\right)=V_{4}=V_{B}=1 \\ \omega_{2}\left(I_{24} I_{12}\right)=1 \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta &=\tan ^{-1}(4 / 3)=53.13010 \\ \alpha &=90^{\circ}-\theta=36.869 \\ \cos \alpha &=\frac{3}{I_{12} I_{24}} \\ I_{12} I_{24} &=\frac{3}{\cos 36.869}=3.7499 \mathrm{meter} \\ \text{Now}, & \omega_{2}(3.7499)=1 \\ \omega_{2} &=\frac{1}{3.7499}=0.266 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q48
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} D &=\sqrt{d^{2}+4 d h}=\sqrt{15^{2}+4 \times 15 \times 10} \\ &=28.723 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q50

question: Q51
solution: Max. Z=100 x P + 80 x Q [latex]\begin{aligned} 5P+3Q&\leq 150\\ P+Q&\leq 40\\ \frac{P}{30}+\frac{Q}{30}&=1 \end{aligned} [/latex] Putting value of corner point in objective function Z(A)=3200 Z(B)=3500 Z(C)=3000 Maximum at B, P=15, Q=25

question: Q52
solution: SPT rule given shortest average Job flow time So, applying SPT Average job flow time [latex] =\frac{124}{4}=31\text{days}[/latex]

question: Q53
solution: Over travel length is given by [latex]=\sqrt{d(D-d)}=\sqrt{2(34-2)}=8[/latex] Estimated maching time per pass is given by [latex]=\frac{Block\;length+Approach+over \;travel}{Table\;feed}=\frac{200+8+8}{18}=12\;min[/latex]

question: Q54
solution: [latex]d^{2}=20\mathrm{mm}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{s} &=200 \mathrm{mm} \\ u_{2} &=0.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ g &=9.8 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ u_{3} &=? \\ u_{2} &=\sqrt{2 g h_{c}} \\ 0.5 &=\sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times h_{c}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad h_{c}&=0.01274 \mathrm{m}\\ h_{t}&=h_{s}+h_{c}=0.200+0.01274\\ &=0.2127 \mathrm{m} \\ u_{3} &=\sqrt{2 g h_{t}}=\sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.2127} \\ &=2.043 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Q55
solution: Let us assume the speed is [latex]x\;\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} x T_{1}^{0.1} &=150 \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{1} &=\left(\frac{150}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.1}} \text { and } x T_{2}^{0.3}=300\\ T_{2}&=\left(\frac{300}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.3}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now [latex]T_{2}>T_{1} [/latex] [latex] \text { or }\left(\frac{300}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.3}}=\left(\frac{150}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.1}}[/latex] For solving inequality [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(\frac{300}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.3}}&=\left(\frac{150}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.1}}\\ \text{or }\quad\left(\frac{300}{x}\right)^{0.1}&=\left(\frac{150}{x}\right)^{0.3} \\ \text{or }\quad\quad \frac{x^{0.3}}{x^{0.1}}&=\frac{150^{03}}{300^{01}} \\ \text{or }\quad x&=106.066 \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: Stuart's commander-in-chief was moved by this demonstration of his prejudice.
options.B: The Europeans were accommodating of the sepoy's desire to wear their caste-marks.
options.C: Stuart's 'losing-battle' refers to his inability to succeed in enabling sepoys to wear caste-marks.
options.D: The commander-in-cheif was exempt from the Europeans prejudice that dictated how the sepoys were to dress.
